Great video.  I'll offer some quick agronomic advice for your sweet corn patch.  Corn does not compete well with other grass type plants and the grassy areas along the sides of the rows and close to the base of the plants are doing damage to your corn.  This area is also very low on nitrogen and that is causing the bright yellow streaks on the lower leaves.  If you can come up with a way to reduce the grass pressure and increase soil nitrogen content you will grow some awesome corn!

Little birds can take off from a stand by jumping into the air. Medium-sized birds like crows can do this too, but you can see that it's a big effort. Heavy birds like waterfowl need a running start and sometimes even a headwind. Either way, they need to do something to get into the air before they start flapping.
Also, what they do with their wings is more like swimming than flapping and it takes some practice for them to develop that coordination. Sometimes you see baby birds just out of the nest flapping furiously but not achieving very much.

I took a photo of a chaffinch (in the UK) on a table.  It was quite a wide shot and when I looked, the bird had used gravity to fall from the table edge before starting to fly.  It happened so fast that I had never noticed anything like that before, but it was fascinating.  I have chickens and I love to sit and watch them, it's very calming and I enjoy them very much.  If you love birds too, then there are three books I highly recommend.  The first is "Feathers" by Thor Hansen (he's done one on seeds and another on bees too, he is a great writer) and the second and third are "The Most Perfect Thing: Inside (and Outside) a Bird’s Egg", and "Bird Sense: What It's Like to Be a Bird", both by Tim Birkhead.  The main thing which sticks with me is Heinrich Wickmann and his pencil up a hen's bottom.......but it was a great scientific experiment (and the hen apparently never complained.....) and he found out something new which has since been shown with live X-rays but otherwise couldn't be seen and which we still might not even think about otherwise.....it's all fascinating stuff.  Sorry for rambling, I love birds too.

So maybe make your rows shorter but wider and you will have better quality ears come harvest.

I feel like the tail movement is more dynamic than 'bringing it up to prepare for flight'.. rather, it's like a small fin when swimming; it controls the altitude of the bird's body, as well as providing minimal thrust itself.. toward the end, it looked like the bird was giving all it could to get a bit more vertical before it would bring the tail up in line with flight. As the tail moves up it would change the birds entire profile because of both position and drag, and give the first initial forward thrust to help the wings 'grip' the air and facilitate momentum.
I paraglide, sail, swim and dive, and find the parallels between hydro and aero dynamics interesting.. basically the same stuff if you allow for differences in weight/resistance.

It's probably apocryphal, but the hopping for take off attribute has been a feature of kung fu lore for centuries. The story goes that masters would train their reaction time by holding a bird in their flat palm (obviously a pet not wild) and wait for it to attempt to launch. Then they would collapse their palm without grasping with their fingers to counteract the birds hop and prevent it from taking flight. I always thought that story was just kung fu fantasy. Here in this video I saw that while the whole reaction time thing on a human's part is probably fantasy, it does look as if collapsing a hand under the bird could possibly prevent it from launching. This "delamination" effect has really got me inspired! Is that your term? It's a good one. It reminds me of louvers, like in window blinds. You flatten the louvers and you've got a smooth surface, rotate the louvers and the surface area has basically disappeared. And at first glance, the louver effect looks to be passive. Like, the feathers naturally twist open on the backstroke, and closed on the downstroke. A way to "ratchet" through the air. Imagine this kind of thing done with a kayak paddle, or an airplane wing, so many potential possibilities for oscillating systems!

Back in the early 90s before the advent of consumer digital cameras I worked on the renovation of a cottage that was built on a steep hillside. We were adding a second floor to the building and while we were working we noticed a birds nest just outside a rough opening for a window. It was not much bigger than a shot glass with four of the tiniest eggs you can imagine. It was a hummingbird nest! We were able to watch something few people have seen. We got to see a hummingbird with its wings actually at rest. We saw four newly hatched hummingbird chicks and watched them grow until they were too big for the nest. Mama and Papa bird took turns going for food which seemed to be a 24/7 job.
Was one of the most amazing things I have witnessed. I wish I had pictures to share.

The cornses look very sad.  Next year try companion planting with peas or beans and winter squash.  The three "sisters" of gardening.  They all have different root depths so they won't be competing for nutrients.  Plant the peas/beans when the corn is about 6-8 inches tall and they'll use the corn stalks as their trellis to grow on. The squashes should be planted about every 5 feet or so in between the corn so that as they grow the big leaves shade the ground and help with water retention of the soil.

might not be too relevant, but theres a cool book by Thor Hanson called "Feathers" (if you havent already checked it out) that has a passage about Ken Dial, who sought to find the evolutionary key for why young birds begin to flap. heres a cool excerpt:

"Working together with Terry (who has since gone on to study animal locomotion), Ken came up with a series of ingenious experiments, filming the birds as they raced up textured ramps tilted at increasing angles. As the incline increased, the partridges began to flap, but they angled their wings differently from birds in flight. They aimed their flapping down and backward, using the force not for lift but to keep their feet firmly pressed against the ramp. “It’s like the spoiler on the back of a race car,” he explained, which is a very apt analogy. In Formula One racing, spoilers are the big aerodynamic fins that push the cars downward as they speed along, increasing traction and handling. The birds were doing the very same thing with their wings to help them scramble up otherwise impossible slopes."

again, not totally relevant, but it was a passage in the SAT, so it was an interesting read for that otherwise bland test

Great video, but if you like birds in flight and slow motion you should set up a hummingbird feeder and film some of them. Did you know that the hummingbirds brain, though pea size, is the largest brain relative to size, of all birds. The brain is 4.2% of total body weight. By comparison, our brains are only 2 percent of our body weight. A bit embarrassing to know, that a tiny bird that weighs mere grams has a brain larger than humans in a way. The hummingbird can even fly upside down and can remember items. They can figure out how long to wait between visits so the flowers have time to generate more nectar. They can even recognize humans, and know which ones can be counted on to refill empty hummingbird feeders.
So filming hummingbirds would would be a bit of a challenge, but think of all that you could learn from them.

In my mind what is more interesting is what can be learned from Destin himself. You can see from the video when releasing the bird that his reactions are slower than the birds flight. When opening his hand he is understandably looking into his hand at the bird, but between the bird taking off and it leaving the frame, his eyes lag from following the bird. Clearly eyes do not do well with tracking an object, they jump from point to point due to a lack of fine motor movement, but this requires interpolation of where the object of desire will be.

His brain is working out from the movement it felt and saw where the bird is likely to be when it has had a chance to catch up, and moves his eyes to a position such that he has the bird passing through his centre of focus, while adjusting his head, and focal point, and generally tracking the bird.

What this makes me wonder is are new borns or certainly very young children capable of this interpolation; how do they track object differently; do some people over estimate, and jump ahead of the object?

I have some scrub jays that live in my yard; I feed them and they're used to me for the most part. One thing I've observed is that they very obviously enjoy their ability to fly. They are constantly pulling all kinds of stunts to show off. Another thing I've observed is that they're very efficient in their flight. Jumping off the ground is always more efficient than flapping off the air. As they fly from my driveway up and over my house, they cut it close enough to the gutter to push off of it. And, I believe, when they fly down from the wire or the garage to the driveway (where there's a horizontal component as well as a downwards one), their path follows a brachistochrome.

The tail on birds gives marginal stability even at full flight speed- modern birds have very small tails for their body size, and certainly will rely on small movements of their wings to maintain control at low speeds. They also have unusually large balance organs, so they can sense what their bodies are doing, so they can react really fast. Having a small tail makes them much more manoeuvrable so they can better evade predators and is lighter, which saves energy.

This video reminded me of a few weeks ago when I was entering my church at night to take out the garbage. I saw what looked like a leaf on the floor in the foyer, but when I turned on the lights I noticed that it was not a leaf, it was a bat. It was alive, and too exhausted to move, so I scooped it up with a couple of pieces of paper (it was small, maybe a few ounces). As I got it onto the paper, I noticed that one of its upper claws was hooked on the edge of the paper, spreading the digits out. It is remarkable how much they look like fingers. Anyway, I brought it outside and placed it on the ground between two trees so it could climb to safety. (Unfortunately,I later discovered that it did not survive.)

I'm guessing that the tail pointing downward as it takes off is a balance thing, not a drag thing. When I was younger my siblings and I had a few small pet birds, and they would point their tail down at various angles to maintain balance. Their feathers were clipped just enough to prevent them from flying off, but sometimes, when perched on a wooden dowel in their cage, they would flap for a few seconds anyway, and when doing this their tail feathers would point down. So I'm thinking that it's a balance thing on takeoff but turns into a control surface during horizontal flight.
